I once heard that among the Ká¹£atriyas there was a king named Candragupta, who conquered eastern India. After pacifying it, his prestige was brilliant and his blessings were complete. On his way back to his country, he stopped to rest in a flat place on the road.

With a retinue of a thousand people, he went to the stupa. Not far from the stupa, he dismounted and proceeded on foot, wearing a jeweled celestial crown that adorned his head. Having arrived at the stupa, he bowed his head in reverence and spoke this verse:
Free from the bonds of desire, endowed with omniscience,

At that time, the king, because of recollecting the merits and virtues of the TathÄgata, bowed his head in reverence. When he did so, the stÅ«pa crumbled and scattered, like being blown away by a violent wind.

The one with the ten powers and great authority, so revered and exalted,

From ancient times I have prostrated with my five limbs and paid homage to hundreds of thousands of stupas, never damaging even a single dust mote. Why is it now changed like this?

He then spoke a verse, saying:
Are the gods and asuras fighting a great battle?
Is the country about to be destroyed, and will my life be exhausted?
Is there an enemy who wants to destroy my country?

At that time, the villagers near the stupa saw the king's doubts and suspicions, and immediately said to the king, Great King!

And spoke a verse, saying:
The Nirgranthas are extremely foolish, their minds burned by wrong views,

In this way, wood and stone have no consciousness, yet they serve as a clear proof for the Nirgrantha, knowing that he is not omniscient.
Having seen this, the king joyfully leapt in front of the great assembly, his faith doubled, his countenance relaxed and delighted, and he said:

Among all beings, whether with one foot, two feet, no feet, or many feet, with form or formless, with thought or without thought, up to neither thought nor non-thought, within this assembly, only the TathÄgata is the most honored and supreme.
To summarize, what the Buddha has said is all manifested today, and all non-Buddhists are not as insignificant as grass and chaff, let alone the teachers Nirgrantha and PÅ«raá¹‡a KÄÅ›yapa?
Then he spoke a verse, saying:

Let alone the wheel-turning king, the asura kings, and so forth!
This stÅ«pa today is as if for the great elephant king,
With the power of tusks and feet, it is crushed and destroyed.
The body is endowed with four kinds of bonds, therefore called Nirgrantha.
Just like in the great heat, it can remove that heat,
Called Nirgrantha;
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored Buddha, can sever all bonds, truly Nirgrantha.
For this reason, today, the disciples of Nirgrantha,
And all the other gods and humans, should all make offerings to the Buddha.
The wisdom of the Buddha's lineage, with a very vast reputation,
Such a stupa, by devas, humans, and asuras,
If they pay homage to it, there will be no sign of shaking.
Like a mosquito's wing fanning Mount Sumeru,
Although it exhausts its strength, it cannot cause it to move.

(32) Furthermore, even if a person's conduct is flawed, they can still attain the Way through the power of learning. For this reason, one should diligently study.
I once heard that there was a very learned monk who lived in a secluded place. A widow often came to this monk to listen to his teachings.

At that time, the monk who was studying became attached to the widow. Because of this attachment, his wholesome dharmas gradually weakened. Bound by the afflictions of an ordinary person's mind, he made a promise with the woman.
The woman said:
If you can now give up the monastic life and return to lay life, I will follow you.
At that time, the monk immediately gave up the monastic life.

Having given up the monastic life, he was unable to endure the suffering of the world. His body became emaciated. He did not know how to make a living, nor did he know how to earn much wealth with little effort. He then thought to himself:
What plan can I use to make a living now?
He further thought:
Only butchers who slaughter sheep have extremely light work and also earn much profit.
Having had this thought, he sought out such a place. Because the mind of an ordinary person easily decays, he created this karma. He eventually became close friends with the butchers.

When selling the meat, there was a familiar beggar monk who happened to meet him on the road and recognized him. Seeing his disheveled hair, blue clothes, and blood on his body, he was like a Yama demon. The meat scale he held was all stained with blood.
Seeing him selling the meat to people, the bhiká¹£u sighed deeply and thought like this:
The Buddha's words are true!
The mind of ordinary beings is fickle and unstable, extremely easy to turn.
Previously I saw this person diligently studying and upholding the precepts. How could it be that today he would do such a thing?
Having had this thought, he immediately spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½If you do not tame the horse,
and recklessly commit various evils,
How can you be free from shame and abandon the method of self-control?ğŸ”½One's deportment and conduct
are what people enjoy seeing,ğŸ”½And even flying birds and running beasts
are not frightened upon seeing it.
Walking, fearing to harm ants, compassionate and caring for sentient beings,
Such a compassionate mind, where is it now?
Ordinary people's minds are unstable, they can only be called Å›ramaá¹‡as and brahmins in name, therefore the TathÄgata does not speak of their characteristics;
If one attains the true view of the four noble truths, then one is called a Å›ramaá¹‡a and a brahmin.
He further spoke a verse, saying:
The valiant one proclaims himself, claiming to be a true Å›ramaá¹‡a,
For this unruly mind, suddenly committing such a great evil.
Having spoken this verse, he immediately thought,
What expedient means can I use to make him enlightened?
As the Buddha said:

'When teaching others, one should first make them give rise to pure faith in the four indestructible [virtues]. These four indestructible [virtues] can enable sentient beings to see the four noble truths.'
Now I shall explain the fundamental basis of karma for him.
Having had this thought, he said to him:
You have weighed it extremely well now.
At that time, the meat seller had this thought:
Since this bhiká¹£u did not buy the meat, why did he tell me that I weighed it extremely well?
Having had this thought, he immediately spoke a verse, saying:
This must be out of compassion, coming to see and rescue!
Such a bhiká¹£u has long been free from the ways of the market,
Seeing that I am doing evil karma, he has come to save and deliver me.
He is truly a sage, bringing benefits to me!

Having spoken this verse, he immediately recalled from the past when he was a bhiká¹£u and created various practices, remembering the sÅ«tras he had recited before, called The Heap of Suffering, the Delusion of Desire, and the Taste of Desire.
Having thought of this, he immediately threw the meat scale far to the ground, deeply giving rise to disgust in the cycle of birth and death, and said to that bhiká¹£u:
Venerable! Venerable!
And spoke this verse:
What is the most of the taste of desire and the faults of desire?ğŸ”½I, with a sense of shame and modesty,
Grasp the scale of wisdom.
Contemplating such matters, my mind has attained penetration,

Therefore, I should now abandon desire,
Go to the monastery, and return to seek renunciation.ğŸ”½I now wish to do this,
Suffering physical pain and extreme humiliation,
Although it is the present body, it is as if fallen into a bad realm.
When I renounced the world in the past, I filtered the water before drinking it,
Compassionately protecting the lives of others, without a harmful mind.
Today, like a vicious ghost, eating human essence and blood,
I now delight in killing and harming, practicing it and unable to let go.
Excellent is the Buddha's teaching, that those who are close to desire,
Do not create any evil.
I now, for the sake of desire, have fallen into this suffering and hardship.
I have not yet realized the Four Truths, from today onwards,
I will never again be negligent.
Those who were previously negligent, later stop and do not do it again,
Like the moon free from clouds and obscurations, illuminating the world.
Therefore, I will now single-mindedly uphold the precepts,
Even if my head is on fire, and my clothes are burning,
I will be steadfast in my diligence, practicing the Dharma of self-discipline,
Cutting off the difficult-to-subdue afflictions, and surely attaining tranquility.
Even if my body is emaciated and my flesh and blood are exhausted,
As long as I do not see the Four Truths, I will never rest,
First extinguishing the enemy of the afflictions, and attaining the victorious reward to bestow grace.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us knew his thoughts. The fire of wisdom was about to ignite, so they spoke a verse, saying:
If you now go forth, you will surely attain liberation.
KÄli, Saá¹ƒkÄ«rti, and CÄ«rÄ,

And later returned to the renunciant life, attaining arhatship.
The precepts of the World-Honored One of the Ten Powers, you also did not violate,
You did not give rise to wrong views, you have the wisdom of much learning,
Giving rise to the good of disgust, cultivating the bliss of tranquility.
You have the lamp of much learning, destroyed by the wind of afflictions,
You should return to cultivating much learning, you will surely reach the state of fearlessness.
Being tossed about by the afflictions, you should rely on the power of cultivating concentration,
Cultivating concentration, attaining the power of insight, clearly seeing the afflictions.
Because you have always cultivated and accumulated, you delight in the Dharma of leaving the household life,
Your mind is close to wholesome qualities, but is destroyed by afflictions,
Cultivating the right path, this mind grasps the afflictions,
Like an elephant freed from shackles, going wherever it pleases.
At that time, the monk who had left the path abandoned evil deeds, left the household life, diligently practiced, and attained the fruit of arhatship.
(33) Furthermore, if one wishes to adorn oneself, nothing surpasses wholesome karma. Therefore, one should diligently cultivate all wholesome deeds.
I once heard that there was a farmer who was intelligent and wise. He came to the city with his companions.

At that time, he saw a person with an upright appearance, adorned with various garments and necklaces, riding in a magnificent carriage, with many attendants all dressed in gorgeous and extraordinary attire.
The intelligent one said to his companions:
Not good, not good.
His companions said:ğŸ”½This person is good-looking, with a handsome appearance, and is well-adorned.
This person has majestic virtue and is upright, deeply lovable and respectable, what is not good about him?
The wise one said:
I am not good myself, nor do I consider him to be bad, because in my previous life I did not create merit, causing me to now receive this lowly body, without majesty or respect from others.
If I had cultivated blessings in the past, how could I be inferior to such a person? Therefore, I should now diligently cultivate goodness, and make sure that in the future I will be superior to him.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
He abandoned heedlessness, cultivated goodness and obtained blessings and benefits,
Because of my heedlessness, I did not cultivate meritorious deeds,
Therefore, I am now poor and lowly, inferior and without majesty or power,
I now shame myself, so I call myself bad.
I now observe myself, poor and lowly, extremely pitiful,
Deceived by afflictions and destroyed by negligence,
From now on I will diligently cultivate giving, morality, and concentration,
Certainly causing future lives to have a good family, close relatives,
Upright appearance, majestic virtue, wealth, and many attendants,
With no faults to be criticized, respected by the world;
Not like today's body, regretting that there is nothing I can do.
Evil thoughts are my enemies, deceiving me to poverty and lowliness,
The mind can repent and reproach itself, cultivating goodness and attaining happiness.
If one creates evil karma, all goodness does not arise,
Those who restrain the mind and cultivate goodness, glory and pleasure are all complete.
The worldly saying is not false, the retribution of good and evil is distinct,
The Buddha speaks of the eightfold right path, which can lead to nirvana.
If the mind is attached to wealth, profit, wealth, nobility, and glory,
Those who seek rebirth will not escape the afflictions of aging and old age.
I should diligently and single-mindedly head towards the direction of fearlessness.
It is like a drunken painter who paints various images,
When sober, he realizes their ugliness and destroys them to create better ones.
Because of foolishness in past lives, I have created this evil body in the present.
I should now destroy evil karma and seek superior rewards in the future.
Having seen the evil fruits of retribution, the wise deeply reproach themselves.
(34) Furthermore, if one hears good teachings, one should contemplate them and will certainly obtain benefits. Therefore, the wise should always listen to and accept the wonderful Dharma.
I once heard that in the country of Shravasti, the Buddha was walking in the wilderness with Ananda, and they saw a hidden treasure in a field.
The Buddha told Ananda:
This is a very poisonous snake.
Ananda said to the Buddha:
This is an evil poisonous snake.
At that time, there was a farmer in the field who heard the Buddha and Ä€nanda say there was a poisonous snake, and he thought like this:
I should go and see, what does the Å›ramaá¹‡a consider to be a poisonous snake?
He then went to the place and saw a heap of real gold, and said this:
What the Å›ramaá¹‡a calls a poisonous snake is actually good gold.
He then took the gold and returned it to his home.
Because that person was previously poor and did not have enough food and clothing, but after obtaining the gold, he became rich and had plenty of food and clothing to enjoy as he pleased.

The royal family's spies found it strange that he suddenly became rich, and they investigated him and put him in prison. The gold he had previously obtained was already used up, and he still could not escape, and was about to be executed.
That person cried out:
A poisonous snake!
Ä€nanda!
A poisonous snake!
World-Honored One!
The people around him heard it and reported it to the king. The king called that person and asked him:
Why do you cry out:ğŸ”½?
'A poisonous snake.'
Ä€nanda!
A vicious poisonous snake.
World-Honored One!'
The man said to the king:
When I was plowing the fields in the past, I heard the Buddha and Ä€nanda say 'poisonous snake' and 'vicious poisonous snake.'
Only now do I realize that it truly is a poisonous snake.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The Buddha's words are without duality, calling it a great poisonous snake.
Ä€nanda addressed the World-Honored One, saying it is indeed a vicious poisonous snake.
The power of the vicious poisonous snake, I now begin to realize and know.
Towards the World-Honored Buddha, I double my faith and respect.
I am now in a perilous situation, therefore I praise the Buddha's words.
What is bitten by a poisonous snake only affects one's body.
Relatives, wives and children, servants and slaves,
All have nothing to do with the one who suffers in pain;
Wealth and treasures are like poisonous snakes, they can harm and kill the entire family and relatives.
Now, I view wealth and treasures, as well as relatives and acquaintances,
As if they were evil poisonous snakes, when anger arises.
The wise should quickly leave, just as one would abandon an evil poisonous snake,
And should quickly seek to go forth, to the mountains and forests.
Who has wisdom, seeing and hearing such things,
And yet would be attached to wealth and treasures, deluded and confused by them?
I thought I was gaining great benefits, but in the end I only brought harm and distress upon myself.
Having heard these verses, the king deeply understood that this person had given rise to a mind of faith and understanding in the Buddha's words, and then spoke a verse, saying:
You are now able to have faith and respect, and compassion for the great sage,
Whose words are true, never uttering two different things.
The wealth and treasures that were previously hidden, I will now use to return them all to you,
To make offerings to you.
Able to respectfully believe in the Tamer, the Well-Gone One's true words,
The Brahma Heaven's place of faith, the Asura of Bala,
The Heavenly Kings and Shakra, we and the various kings,
The nobles in the city, the Brahmins and Kshatriyas,
The superior, victorious, knowledgeable and insightful people, there are none who do not have faith and respect.
Because able to have the same faith as me, presently attains the flower-like reward,
Now believing in the most trustworthy place, should attain the foremost fruit.

(35) Furthermore, those who seek benefits may or may not obtain them. Those with true goodness do not seek to obtain benefits for themselves. Those without true goodness seek to obtain benefits out of greed. Therefore, one should cultivate a true and good mind.

I once heard that there was a king, and the son of a minister whose father had passed away early. The son was still young and not yet able to succeed to the position. His wealth was already exhausted, and no one could bring him to see the king. He lived in poverty.

Gradually growing up, he had the talent of a minister, and was well-versed in governing the people and making judgments. As he reached adulthood, his physical appearance was magnificent, he was brave and strong, and his talents were complete. He thought like this:
I am now poor. What should I do?
Moreover, I cannot do any lowly work.
Now I have no blessings. My talents and skills cannot be put to use. I was also not born into a low-class family. I have heard others say this verse:ğŸ”½Karma comes and transforms me,
My poverty is now like this,ğŸ”½The family business of my parents,
Now there is no place to use it.ğŸ”½The work done by the lowly,
Is not suitable for me to do,
If I have no merit, I should be born into a low-caste family.
Although the family I was born into is noble, the suffering is like this.
Low-caste work is extremely easy to know, but I am unable to do it.
I should engage in private theft, making others completely unaware,
Just as there is the work of robbing, concealing it so that others do not notice.
Tying two arrow quivers to the waist, and carrying a sharp steel sword,
Binding the bow in the hand, adorning oneself in various ways,
Like a lion cub, completely without fear.
Having spoken this verse, he had this thought:
If I rob elsewhere, it may impoverish others, I shall rob the king.

Having had this thought, he went to the king's palace, to the king's sleeping quarters. The king was afraid of the thief, but did not dare speak. He took the king's clothes and all his necklaces and put them in one place.

At that time, by the king's head there was a vessel of water, and beside it was ash. Afflicted by hunger and thirst, he thought the ash was flour, mixed it with water and drank it. After drinking it, he became full and then realized it was ash.
He immediately thought to himself:
Ash can still be eaten, let alone other things.
I would rather eat grass than be a thief.
My father and ancestors did not engage in this occupation.
He then abandoned all the goods and returned home.
The king saw him return empty-handed and exclaimed, Excellent!
He called the man and said to him:
Why did you take these things, then put them back on the ground and return empty-handed?
He replied:
Great King!
Listen to what I have to say.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Why do unprincipled things?
It is because of hunger and thirst. Ash and water stop hunger and thirst, so I stopped my thieving mind.
Now I know that hunger and thirst are easy to stop,
I drank the ash water, threw the vessel on the ground,
and out of shame and regret, I will not commit evil again.
Great king, you should know that I am not an ordinary person,
I am the son of a minister, but because my family is poor,
I came to the king's palace and did improper things.
From this day forward, I will always drink ash water,
eat grass to sustain myself, and not engage in theft.
In my family's past traditions, there are family rules and teachings,
it is better to destroy oneself, than to violate the old teachings.

The king, seeing this, marveled at the unprecedented, and praised the son of a good family as being true and not false. Although he had faults, he was able to repent immediately, and then spoke a verse, saying:
Poverty destroys resolve and endurance, and abandons shame and humility,
ordinary, inferior, and evil people quickly commit evil deeds.
Using the hook of your family's Dharma, you can control the elephant of non-Dharma.
If you can restrain your mind and not go against the teachings of your family,
You will have this virtuous conduct and inherit your father's position.
Now that you have removed your deluded mind and can do difficult things,
I am extremely delighted and appoint you as my prime minister.
There is no need to observe in secret, I have already seen your conduct.
Your mind is firm, your resolve is courageous, and you also have wisdom.
I now see for myself that this is indeed difficult to have.
Your talent and virtue surpass your father's, because your mind is truly good.
Therefore, the wise should be true and not deceptive.
(36) Furthermore, although the present afflictions do not arise, if the bonds have not been severed, the attainment of the afflictions still exists, like cold water poured into hot soup.
I once heard that a teacher and his disciple, during the winter, saw a pile of fire without smoke or flames in a warm room.
The teacher said to the disciple:
Do you see this fire without smoke or flames?
The disciple said:
I see it.
The teacher said to the disciple:
If you add dry firewood, the smoke will immediately rise.
He further said:
Blow with your mouth, and the flames will come out.
The teacher spoke a verse for the disciple, saying:
The fire first has no smoke or flames, like the mind of compassion has no impure contemplation.
Present afflictions do not arise, like fire without smoke or flames.
Just as fire obtains dry firewood, smoke and flames arise simultaneously.
The fire of the mind encounters conditions, meeting with bad friends,
The smoke of anger then arises. If one sees good colors,
The fire of lust blazes.
Accomplishing the three knowledges, in order to cut off greed, hatred, and delusion,
One should diligently cultivate and practice.
The grass of afflictions does not grow, like a constantly traveled road,
Where no other plants can grow.
Not encountering conditions, they do not arise, because the root has not been severed,
Encountering conditions, they arise again.
The four days of concentration manifest, in the third and second days,
Encountering conditions, they arise again.
Also resembling worldly concentration, suppressing the afflictions so they do not arise, there are no signs of trouble at all.
Desire is like the root of a poisonous tree, if not pulled out the sprouts grow again,
Like a person ashamed of their white hair, who shaves off the black ones,
Before long after shaving, the white hair grows back again.
Not permanently severing the afflictions, the matter is also like this,
The bonds of desire and hatred, pressing on the mechanism of precepts and practices,
The antidote hides and does not arise.
Then they give rise to thoughts of difficulty in obtaining, and afflictions arise again later,
Violating and transgressing the precepts and practices.ğŸ”½Craving and indulging in the five desires, like a snake hiding in a hole,
Coming out again to bite people.

Furthermore, giving is for liberation, not for wealth. If it is for wealth, it is not called giving. If it is for liberation, one attains non-arising and the bliss of nirvana. Therefore, the wise should practice giving for liberation.
I once heard that a donor went to the monks' quarters to hold a gathering. A knowledgeable monk said to the senior monk:
Today the donor's food and drink are exquisite. Please speak the Dharma patiently for the donor.

At that time, the senior monk had attained the three insights, the six spiritual powers, and was endowed with the eight liberations. He skillfully observed others' minds and deeply contemplated the purpose of holding this gathering. He then knew that this gathering was held for the sake of wealth and profit.
At that time, the senior monk spoke about the suffering of the three evil paths for this patron, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
The offerings you have prepared now are timely gifts, with perfect color, fragrance, and flavor, extremely pure, with nothing lacking in the three evil paths.
Then the knowledgeable monk said to the senior monk:
Why do you chant blessings for the three evil paths, saying that they have nothing lacking?
Then the senior monk said to the monk's son:

Although I am old and may have erred in speaking the Dharma, this patron does not practice the precepts and is driven by afflictions. I observe his mind and speak thus. This patron is for the sake of the pleasures of the five desires and wealth like an animal.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Where the giver is born, wealth and treasures are extremely vast,
And because of relying on wealth and treasures, he can give rise to arrogance.
Arrogance and pride violate the Dharma, the blind and deluded ordinary person,
Because of violating the Dharma, they fall into the three evil destinies.
Dwelling in the three evil paths, it is like one's own house,
If born in the human or heavenly realms, it is like a temporary guest.
Therefore, the companions of precepts and giving, together attain nirvana,
Precepts can lead to rebirth in the heavens, giving can provide all the necessary things,
What is done is for liberation, and will surely end the cycle of suffering.
It is like planting lotus roots, the flowers and leaves are all obtained,
The roots can also be eaten.
Approaching the forest of liberation, the joy is like the flowers and leaves,
The roots are likened to liberation.
Therefore, cultivating precepts and giving, one must attain liberation, and should not seek worldly benefits.
Furthermore, it is difficult to be free from difficulties, and it is difficult to obtain a human body. Having obtained freedom from difficulties, one should always be diligent.
I once heard that a young child heard it said in a sutra:
A blind turtle encountering a hole in a floating log is extremely difficult.

At that time, the child deliberately drilled a hole in a board to fit his head, threw it into a pond, and himself entered the pond, raising and lowering his head, hoping to get the head into the hole, but the water floated the board away, so he could not find it.
He then thought to himself:

Extremely disgusted, it is difficult to obtain a human body. The Buddha uses the great ocean as a metaphor, the hole in the floating log is small, and the blind turtle has no eyes, appearing once every hundred years, truly difficult to encounter.
Now my pond is small, the hole in the board is large, and I have two eyes, appearing a hundred times a day, yet I still cannot find it, let alone that blind turtle being able to encounter it?
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The great ocean is extremely vast, and the hole in the floating wood is very small,
Emerging once every hundred years, it is extremely difficult to encounter.
Now my pond is small, and the hole in the floating wood is extremely large,
Emerging again and again, I cannot encounter the hole in the wood.
The blind turtle encountering the floating wood, it is extremely difficult to meet,
The evil paths and the human body, encountering it is also difficult like this.
I now encounter the human body, I should not be negligent,
